p: Alongside traditional goals of collecting, conserving, and communicating (“finished” science, for example), fourth-generation science museums can be places for activism, reflecting more contemporary and forward-looking goals that speak to present-day museums’ changing landscapes. Janes and Sandell (2019) write about “new and divergent expressions of the museum’s inherent power as a force for good” (p. 1), as a catalyst for change. In a time of, for example, COVID-19, environmental degradation, advances in reproductive technologies, waste management issues, oil extraction, and global warming, science museums can become another player and voice for social, environmental, and political transformation (Janes, 2009; Ng et al., 2017).
